The Efficacy and Safety of OnabotulinumtoxinA or Solifenacin Compared with Placebo in Solifenacin-Naïve Patients w…

citation.abstract:
This double-blind, randomized study compared the efficacy/safety of onabotulinumtoxinA or solifenacin versus placebo in overactive bladder patients with urinary incontinence who had an inadequate response to/were intolerant of an anticholinergic. A post-hoc analysis compared effects of onabotulinumtoxinA versus solifenacin.
Solifenacin-naïve patients were randomized to onabotulinumtoxinA 100U, solifenacin 5mg (could escalate to 10mg at week 6 with predefined criteria), or placebo. Patients could request treatment 2 (open-label onabotulinumtoxinA) after fulfilling prespecified criteria. Endpoints included change from baseline in urinary incontinence episodes/day and proportions of patients with 100% reduction ("dry") in incontinence episodes/day (co-primaries), other urinary symptoms, and quality of life, all at week 12, and adverse events.
Change from baseline in incontinence episodes/day was significantly greater with onabotulinumtoxinA (-3.19) or solifenacin (-2.56) vs placebo (-1.33; both p<0.001 vs placebo); incontinence reduction was significantly greater for onabotulinumtoxinA vs solifenacin (p=0.022). At week 12, 33.8% (p<0.001 vs placebo), 24.5% (p=0.028 vs placebo), and 11.7% of onabotulinumtoxinA, solifenacin, and placebo patients were "dry," respectively; after treatment 2 (open-label onabotulinumtoxinA), 43.2%, 37.6%, and 41.9% of patients in each respective group were "dry." Significant improvements in other urinary symptoms and quality of life were observed in both active treatments. Urinary tract infection (25.5%) and retention (6.9%) were more common with onabotulinumtoxinA.
The efficacies of both onabotulinumtoxinA and solifenacin were significantly higher than placebo, but onabotulinumtoxinA showed significantly greater reductions in urinary incontinence than solifenacin, with one-third achieving 100% incontinence reduction. No unexpected safety signals were observed.
citation.title: The Efficacy and Safety of OnabotulinumtoxinA or Solifenacin Compared with Placebo in Solifenacin-Naïve Patients with Refractory Overactive Bladder: Results from a Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind, Phase 3b Trial
